results.title: Witness for the prosecution
results.creator_credit: Billy Wilder, Arthur Hornblow and Theme Pictures
results.brief_description: Director Billy Wilder’s acclaimed 1957 courtroom melodrama based on Agatha Christie’s hit London play left audiences reeling from its surprise twists and shocking climax. Charles Laughton, Tyrone Power, Marlene Dietrich and Elsa Lanchester make this Oscar nominated classic a rivetiing experience. When a wealthy widow is found murdered, her married suitor, Leonard Vole (Power) is accused of the crime. At his trial, everyone is stunned when the prosecution calls Vole’s wife (Dietrich) to testify against him. Now it is more difficult than ever for Vole’s flamboyant defence attorney (Laughton) to prove that his client is innocent.

results.title: Without you I'm nothing
results.creator_credit: John Boskovich, Jonathan Krane and M.C.E.G.
results.brief_description: Based on Sandra Bernhard’s one-woman live show, “Without You I’m Nothing” is an ecstatic celebration of deviancy and sexual difference. Bernhard is a sardonic and biting comedian who in a series of inspired personas exposes the hypocrisy and shallowness that dominate contemporary American culture. Whether sending up her suburban Jewish upbringing or the excesses of Hollywood stardom, Bernhard’s stand-up routines reclaim the transgressive bitchiness of camp. “Without You I’m Nothing” achieves much of its power from the sheer force of Bernhard’s personality. Whether performing a lesbian-tinted “Me and Mrs Jones” or stripping to “Do You Want To Funk?”, her energy is explosive and exhilarating to watch. For lesbian and gay viewers, there is also the elation of watching a performer unapologetically celebrate the unique mixture of the kitsch, the erotic and the subversive which is central to queer notions of community and identity. The film also celebrates the pivotal contribution of African-Americans to popular music, and acknowledges how this contribution has been largely stripped of its innovation and urgency when exploited by white performers. Wicked, intelligent, sophisticated and fun, “Without You I’m Nothing” is a key work of the new Queer Cinema.

results.title: Without a sound
results.creator_credit: Michael Henry, University of Melbourne, Victorian College of the Arts and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: Thomas is an insurance investigator called out on the eve of his wife leaving, to attend a mysterious fire in which an unknown boy has been killed. Going through the motions while awaiting a call from his wife, Thomas - like the viewer, is drawn into the mysteries of the fire. (Awards: Best Cinematography, nominated Best Film, Best Sound, VCA, 1998)

results.title: Withnail & I
results.creator_credit: Bruce Robinson, Paul Heller and HandMade Films
results.brief_description: Screenwriter Bruce Robinson made his directorial debut with this British comedy which portrays the last throes of an eccentric friendship during the final days of the sixties. Withnail and “I” (or Marwood) are both unsuccessful and unemployed actors. Bound together by poverty and dreams of stardom, they share a flat of indescribable squalor and live on a diet of alcohol, pills and pot. Withnail is fast becoming a burned-out relic of the sixties, while Marwood is trying to reassimilate into society. The two decide to spend a soul-cleansing week in the country in a primitive cottage borrowed from Withnail’s eccentric uncle Monty, but things go from worse to even worse and their dreams of an idyllic retreat rapidly degenerate into an hilarious nightmare. Cast includes Richard E. Grant, Paul McGann, Richard Griffiths, Ralph Brown and Michael Elphick.

results.title: Uluru: an Anangu story (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: David Roberts, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This is the history of Uluru from an aboriginal perspective, from the dawn of creation to the celebrations on October 26, 1985, when Uluru was handed back to the traditional owners. Presented with humour and sensitivity are re-enactments of the creation stories, the experience of the Anangu during their first contact with white people and minga (tourists) performing their strange rituals.

results.title: Ultra shorts: 1994 V.C.A. compilation
results.creator_credit: Tony D'Aquino, Daniel Crooks, Guy Richards, Sima Urale, Emma Kelly, Jolyon Watkins, Beckett Broda and Victorian College of the Arts
results.brief_description: Selection of seven short films by students from the Victorian College of the Arts. “The Baron”: A Young man recalls his friendship with an eccentric misfit who thinks he is the Red Baron. “Toll”: Tense, surreal drama inspired by the horror of the road toll. “Ultra vires”: An animated film about the mythical struggle between a girl and a dragon. “Burning moths”: A girl in white visits the share house from hell. “Trumpet”: Poignant story of a boy’s effort to win his father’s approval. “Food (for) thought: (three) ingredients from the mass consumer diet”: An animated film about bread, religion and television. “Lost and vicious”: Noir nasties fight it out on the highway at night.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tony D’Aquino, Daniel Crooks, Guy Richards, Sima Urale, Emma Kelly, Jolyon Watkins, Beckett Broda and Victorian College of the Arts

results.title: Ulee's gold
results.creator_credit: Victor Nunez, Clinica Estetico and Orion Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: This touching film presents a subtle study of the difficulties and complexities involved in the development and maintenance of lasting human relations. It reveals how abnormal events force one self-exiled loner to reassess his moral and emotional beliefs and to redeem his sense of personal and familial strength. Ulee, a Vietnam veteran turned beekeeper, in the tradition of generations before him, watches his family disintegrate when his son, Jimmy, lands in jail for robbery and his daughter-in-law disappears, leaving their two daughters in Ulee’s care. Ulee takes refuge from this state of affairs in the production of his high-grade honey with the unspoken assistance of his youngest granddaughter. However, when Jimmy’s partners begin threatening his family, thinking that Jimmy has hidden the proceeds of their robbery, Ulee’s stubbornly suppressed sense of the unconditional bond and care that links his family begins to surface and he becomes involved in the tenuous situation. Nunez handles this film with a simplicity and sensitivity that effectively evokes the personal journey of Ulee and the rest of his family in challenging circumstances.

results.title: Ulcer at work
results.creator_credit: Ned Hockman and University of Oklahoma
results.brief_description: Looks at the way in which emotional problems can cause ulcers, and illustrates the prescribed mental attitudes and dietary procedures necessary for curing a peptic ulcer in its preliminary stage.
results.description: Looks at the way in which emotional problems can cause ulcers, and illustrates the prescribed mental attitudes and dietary procedures necessary for curing a peptic ulcer in its preliminary stage.

results.title: Ukrainian dance
results.creator_credit: Laura Boulton and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Music and dances are performed by the Ukrainian Canadians of Manitoba, largest Slavonic group in Canada. The first part of the film shows the customs and religious ceremonies at holidays for these people. Four dances comprise the second part of the film: the Bird Dance, the Cossack Dance, the Cossack War Dance, and the Catherina Dance.
